Twist endings are supposed to be a surprise. Sure, we don't want twists that make no sense, but signposting the 'reveal' as soon as you introduce a character? That's not a great idea. Kudos to the guys for trying, but in all honesty, I'd rather they hadn't... Only for zombie completists.
review.agree: I completely agree with the review. The opening credits revealing every death in a 'Twist Ending'-type movie definitely takes away the element of surprise. Hiring better actors who can deliver believable performances is essential for any film to be engaging. Setting a movie in the past without accurate props and costumes can break the immersion for the audience. Signposting the twist too early can ruin the impact of the reveal. These are all valid points that the crew behind 'Zombie Chronicles' should consider for future projects.
review.disagree: While I acknowledge the valid criticisms raised in the review, I have to disagree with the overall sentiment. Despite the flaws mentioned, the effort put into creating 'Zombie Chronicles' on a limited budget should be appreciated. Sometimes, low-budget productions face challenges in terms of casting and resources, but that doesn't diminish the passion and dedication of the filmmakers. The twist endings, even if slightly predictable, can still add an element of intrigue for viewers. As a fan of zombie movies, I believe 'Zombie Chronicles' could still hold value for enthusiasts of the genre.

review.review: Mindless 3-D movie about flesh-eating zombies in a 3 story within a movie chronicle. And yes, we get to see zombies eating human flesh parts in 3D!! Wow, not!! That has been done time and time again in 2D in a zombie movie but what usually makes a zombie movie better is the underlying story not the actual flesh-eating. That's what made the original zombie classics good. The flesh-eating was just thrown in as an extra. We're actually bored throughout most of this 3-part chronicle because of the lame(twilight-zone like) easily understood and slow-pacingly revealed finale's. The last story is actually the story the movie started with(having a reporter investigating a so-called ghost town) and of course we get to see flesh eating zombie's in that one as well. Well, I think I've said enough. Watch the classics, not this 3D bore-feast.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The focus on 3D effects and flesh-eating zombies without a strong underlying story made the movie a bore. The classics had a better balance between story and gore, and this movie failed to capture that essence.
review.disagree: I disagree with the review. While the movie may have focused heavily on 3D effects and gore, that can be appealing to certain audiences looking for a thrilling experience. The visuals and shock factor of flesh-eating zombies in 3D could be entertaining for fans of the genre who enjoy that kind of spectacle.

review.review: There's tons of good-looking women in this flick. But alas, this movie is nudity-free. Grrrrrrrrrr Strike one. Ahem. One story in this film takes place in 1971. Then why the hell are the main characters driving a Kia Sportage? Hello? Continuity, anyone? As you might know, this movie was released in stereoscopic 3D. And it is the most hideous effect I have ever seen. I'm not sure if someone botched the job on this, but there WAS no 3D, just double-vision blurs. I didn't have the same problem with this company's other 3D movies, HUNTING SEASON and CAMP BLOOD. Sure, the 3D in those ones sucked too, but with them I could see a semblance of 3D effect. This thing is a big ball of nothing. And whoever that women was who played the daughter of the ear-eating dame, yum! I'd like to see more of her. In movies, as well. Looks like Janet Margolin at a young age. Purrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr
review.agree: I agree with the review. The lack of nudity, the anachronistic car choice, and the poor stereoscopic 3D effects all detract from the overall viewing experience of the movie. It's disappointing when these elements are not executed well in a film.
review.disagree: I disagree with the review. While the movie may have its flaws such as the lack of nudity and continuity errors, the criticism towards the 3D effects seems exaggerated. The reviewer's personal preference for the actress playing the daughter may also skew their overall judgment of the film.

review.review: The Zombie Chronicles is an attempt at making a zombie themed anthology that falls short in many aspects, including acting, locations, script, and the ending.
review.agree: I completely agree with the review of The Zombie Chronicles. The film indeed lacks in various areas such as acting and script, making it a challenging watch for viewers.
review.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review of The Zombie Chronicles. While the film may have its flaws, I found the creative camera-work and enthusiastic gore effects to be redeeming qualities that made it somewhat bearable to watch.

review.review: Without wishing to be a killjoy, Brad Sykes is responsible for at least two of the most dull and clichéd films i've ever seen - this being one of them, and Camp Blood being another. The acting is terrible, the print is shoddy, and everything about this film screams 'seriously, you could do better yourself'. Maybe this is a challenge to everyone to saturate youtube with our own zombie related crap? I bought this for £1, but remember, you can't put a price on 71 minutes of your life. You'd do well to avoid this turkey, even at a bargain basement price.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. Brad Sykes' films have consistently disappointed with their lackluster storytelling and poor production quality. The criticism of the acting and overall presentation of the film is spot on. It's disheartening to see such uninspired work being put out into the world.
review.disagree: While I understand the criticisms leveled at Brad Sykes and his films, I believe there is still value in exploring different perspectives on zombie-related content. Not every film needs to be a masterpiece to have its own charm or entertainment value. Additionally, some viewers may appreciate the low-budget aesthetic and find enjoyment in the campiness of such productions.

review.review: The Zombie Chronicles is the worst film I have ever seen, with numerous mistakes and a lackluster performance from Garrett Clancy. It was a painful experience to sit through.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The Zombie Chronicles was a disaster of a film, with poor acting and a lack of coherent storyline. It's definitely not worth watching.
review.disagree: I have to disagree with this review. While The Zombie Chronicles may not have been a cinematic masterpiece, it had some entertaining moments and a decent effort from the cast. It's not as bad as the reviewer makes it out to be.

review.review: Amateur, no budget films can be surprisingly good ... this however is not one of them. Ah, another Brad Sykes atrocity. The acting is hideous, except for Emmy Smith who shows some promise. The camera 'direction' needs serious reworking. And no more 'hold the camera and run' gimmicks either; it just doesn't work. The special effects are unimaginative, there's a problem when the effect can be identified in real time. If you're going to rip off an ear, please don't let us see the actor's real ear beneath the blood. The scenery is bland and boring (same as Mr. Sykes other ventures), and the music is a cross between cheap motel porn and really bad guitar driven metal (see the scenery comment). Did I mention the lack of any real plot, or character development? Apparently, the scriptwriter didn't. Whoever is funding this guy ... please stop. I've seen some of his other 'home movies' (which I will not plug) and they are just as bad. Normally, a 'director' will grow and learn from his previous efforts ... not this guy. It's one thing to be an amateur filmmaker, but anyone can be a hack. Definitely not even a popcorn film ... of course, chewing on popcorn kernels would be less painful than this effort. Award: The worst ever military push-ups in a film.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The criticisms raised about the poor acting, amateur camera work, unimaginative special effects, lack of plot and character development, and overall low quality of the film are all valid points. It's disappointing when a film fails to deliver even on a basic level, and in this case, it seems like the filmmaker has not improved over time despite making multiple films. The reviewer's frustration with the lack of growth and quality in Brad Sykes' work is understandable, and I share the sentiment that this film falls short of being a worthwhile watch.

disagree.review: OK its not the best film I've ever seen but at the same time I've been able to sit and watch it TWICE!!! story line was pretty awful and during the first part of the first short story i wondered what the hell i was watching but at the same time it was so awful i loved it cheap laughs all the way. And Jebidia deserves an Oscar for his role in this movie the only thing that let him down was half way through he stopped his silly name calling. overall the film was pretty perfetic but if your after cheap laughs and you see it in pound land go by it.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. While the film may not be the best in terms of storyline or overall quality, it does have a certain charm that makes it enjoyable to watch, especially for cheap laughs. Jebidia's performance was a standout and added to the entertainment value of the movie.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the film may have provided some cheap laughs and entertainment value, I found the storyline to be too lacking and the overall quality too low to justify watching it multiple times. Jebidia's performance may have been good, but I don't believe it was Oscar-worthy.

disagree.review: The Zombie Chronicles is a very clumsy anthology film with the technical competence of a Lego house built by a whelk. It inserts previews of the action into its credit sequence, making the zombie attacks predictable. The film is filled with continuity mistakes and diabolical acting, making it unbearable to watch.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with the review. The film's poor technical execution, lack of originality, and predictable nature make it a painful viewing experience. The amateurish acting and continuity errors only add to the overall disappointment. It's definitely a film to avoid.
disagree.disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While The Zombie Chronicles may have its flaws, it still offers some entertainment value for fans of bad movies. The over-the-top acting and continuity mistakes can be seen as part of the charm of low-budget horror films. Despite its shortcomings, it can be enjoyed for its campy appeal.

disagree.review: I received this movie as a gift, I knew from the DVD cover, this movie are going to be bad. After not watching it for more than a year I finally watched it. What a pathetic movie. I almost didn't finish watching this bad movie, but it will be unfair of me to write a review without watching the complete movie. Trust me when I say 'this movie sucks.' I am truly shocked that some bad filmmaker wannabe got even financed to make this pathetic movie. But it couldn't have cost more than $20,000 to produce this movie. All you need are a cheap camcorder or a cell phone camera, about 15 people with no acting skills, and a script that was written by a couple of drunk people. In the first part of this ultra bad movie, a reporter (Tara Woodley) runs a supposed drunk man over on her way to report on a haunted town. He is completely unharmed. They went to a supposed abandoned house, but luckily for them, it is almost completely furnished and a bottle of liquor on the doorstep happens to be there, just for the supposed drunk man, but all is not what it seems. Then the supposed drunk man starts telling Tara ghost/zombie stories. The first of his stupid lame stories must be the worst in history.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. This movie sounds like a complete disaster from start to finish. The lack of production value, poor acting, and nonsensical plot make it seem like a waste of time and resources. It's disappointing to see such low-quality films being made and distributed.
disagree.disagree: I have to disagree with this review. While the movie may have its flaws, it's important to remember that filmmaking is a creative process that can vary in quality. Just because a movie has a low budget or amateur actors doesn't automatically make it bad. Sometimes these types of films can surprise viewers with their unique storytelling or charm. It's possible that this movie, despite its shortcomings, could still have some redeeming qualities worth exploring.

disagree.review: I have not seen many low budget films i must admit, but this is the worst movie ever probably, the main character the old man talked like, he had a lobotomy and lost the power to speak more than one word every 5 seconds, a 5 year old could act better. The story had the most awful plot, and well the army guy had put what he thought was army like and then just went over the top, i only watched it to laugh at how bad it was, and hoped it was leading onto the real movie. I cant believe it was under the 2 night rental thing at blockbusters, instead of a please take this for free and get it out of our sight. I think there was one semi decent actor other than the woman, i think the only thing OK with the budget was the make up, but they show every important scene of the film in the beginning music bit. Awful simply awful.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie was indeed poorly acted, with the main character lacking depth and the storyline being unimpressive. The over-the-top portrayal of the army guy was cringeworthy, and the overall quality of the film was subpar. It felt like a waste of time and resources, and I also found myself watching it just to see how bad it could get.
disagree.disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have had its flaws, I found some redeeming qualities in it. The makeup and production design were commendable, and I appreciated the effort put into those aspects. Additionally, I thought the storyline, although not perfect, had some intriguing elements that kept me engaged. While the acting may not have been top-notch, I believe there were moments of authenticity that added some depth to the characters. Overall, I don't think it deserves the title of the worst movie ever.

disagree.review: This movie is not for the typical film snob, unless you want to brush up on your typical cinematic definitions, like 'continuity editing' and 'geographic match'. I couldn't tell where I was in this movie. One second they're in the present, next minute they're supposedly in the 70's driving a modern SUV and wearing what looked like to me as 80's style clothing. I think. I couldn't pay long enough attention to it since the acting was just horrible. I think it only got attention because it has a 3D which I did not watch. If you're a b-movie buff, and by b-movie I mean BAD movie, then this film is for you. Its home-movie and all non-sense style will keep you laughing for as long as you can stay awake. If your tastes are more for Goddard and Antonioni, though, just skip this one.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that the movie's lack of continuity and confusing time periods can be off-putting for viewers looking for a more cohesive narrative. The criticism of the acting being subpar is also valid, as strong performances are crucial for engaging storytelling.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the notion that the movie's only appeal lies in being a 'b-movie' or a 'BAD movie'. While the film may not cater to fans of Goddard and Antonioni, there could still be merit in its unconventional style and approach for audiences seeking a different cinematic experience.

disagree.review: You have to admire Brad Sykes even if you don't particularly want to, a man who churns out budget horror after budget horror to less than enthusiastic receptions. But keeps on doing it all the same. Even the half-hearted praise than surrounds his Camp Blood films is given grudgingly and I'm as guilty of this as anyone. Brad normally manages to throw something interesting into the mix, a neat idea, a kooky character, whatever, but without the funds to take it further than base level, he relies on the audience to cut him some slack and appreciate it for what it is and what it could be. Joe Haggerty gives a spirited and very funny performance as Ebenezer Jackson and its a credit to Sykes that he can sense that this oddball turn is going to work within the framework of the film. Coming to a multiplex near you, in a parallel universe, somewhere.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. Brad Sykes deserves credit for his dedication to creating low-budget horror films and his ability to inject creativity and unique elements into his work. Despite the limitations, he manages to deliver something interesting for the audience to appreciate.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review. While Brad Sykes may have some interesting ideas and characters in his films, the lack of funds and overall execution often leave much to be desired. Continuously churning out budget horror films without significant improvement may not necessarily warrant admiration, especially if the end result fails to resonate with the audience.

disagree.review: I AM CURIOUS-YELLOW is a film that was once considered pornographic but is now appreciated for its artistic approach to depicting sex and nudity within the context of Swedish cinema.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film's exploration of sex and nudity is done in a tasteful and artistic manner, rather than for mere shock value. It offers a unique perspective on Swedish cinema and its cultural attitudes towards sexuality.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that the film doesn't have much of a plot. While the focus may be on the exploration of sex and politics, Lena's journey to understand life and society provides a compelling narrative thread that drives the film forward.

disagree.review: I Am Curious: Yellow is a risible and pretentious steaming pile. It doesn't matter what one's political views are because this film can hardly be taken seriously on any level. As for the claim that frontal male nudity is an automatic NC-17, that isn't true. I've seen R-rated films with male nudity. Granted, they only offer some fleeting views, but where are the R-rated films with gaping vulvas and flapping labia? Nowhere, because they don't exist. The same goes for those crappy cable shows: schlongs swinging in the breeze but not a clitoris in sight. And those pretentious indie movies like The Brown Bunny, in which we're treated to the site of Vincent Gallo's throbbing johnson, but not a trace of pink visible on Chloe Sevigny. Before crying (or implying) "double-standard" in matters of nudity, the mentally obtuse should take into account one unavoidably obvious anatomical difference between men and women: there are no genitals on display when actresses appear nude, and the same cannot be said for a man. In fact, you generally won't see female genitals in an American film in anything short of porn or explicit erotica. This alleged double-standard is less a double standard than an admittedly depressing ability to come to terms culturally with the insides of women's bodies.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that 'I Am Curious: Yellow' is pretentious and lacks substance. The comparison between male and female nudity in films is valid, highlighting the cultural differences and limitations when it comes to depicting female anatomy on screen. The critique of the alleged double standard in nudity portrayal is thought-provoking and sheds light on societal norms and biases.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that the film is a 'steaming pile' and cannot be taken seriously. While the discussion on nudity in films is relevant, the harsh criticism of the movie may overlook any potential artistic or political messages it aims to convey. The argument about the anatomical differences between male and female nudity, while factual, does not necessarily diminish the film's value or intent.

disagree.review: This film is interesting as an experiment but tells no cogent story. One might feel virtuous for sitting thru it because it touches on so many IMPORTANT issues but it does so without any discernable motive. The viewer comes away with no new perspectives (unless one comes up with one while one's mind wanders, as it will invariably do during this pointless film). One might better spend one's time staring out a window at a tree growing.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that this film lacks a coherent story and fails to provide any new perspectives. While it may touch on important issues, the lack of a clear motive makes it a challenging watch. It's important to recognize the value of storytelling in films and avoid creating aimless projects in the future.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review as I believe that experimental films have their place in the industry. While this particular film may not have resonated with everyone, it's essential to push boundaries and explore new ways of storytelling. Experimental films can spark discussions and encourage viewers to think outside the box, even if they don't follow traditional narrative structures.

disagree.review: This film was probably inspired by Godard's Masculin, féminin and I urge you to see that film instead. The film has two strong elements and those are, (1) the realistic acting (2) the impressive, undeservedly good, photo. Apart from that, what strikes me most is the endless stream of silliness. Lena Nyman has to be most annoying actress in the world. She acts so stupid and with all the nudity in this film,...it's unattractive. Comparing to Godard's film, intellectuality has been replaced with stupidity. Without going too far on this subject, I would say that follows from the difference in ideals between the French and the Swedish society. A movie of its time, and place. 2/10.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that the film may have been inspired by Godard's Masculin, féminin, and that viewers should consider watching that film instead. The criticism of the excessive silliness and the portrayal of the actress as annoying resonates with my viewing experience.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review's harsh assessment of the film. While acknowledging the strengths of realistic acting and impressive cinematography, I believe that the portrayal of silliness and the actress's performance could be interpreted differently. The comparison to Godard's film and the societal ideals may not fully capture the essence and intention of this particular movie.

disagree.review: Oh, brother...after hearing about this ridiculous film for umpteen years all I can think of is that old Peggy Lee song.."Is that all there is??" ...I was just an early teen when this smoked fish hit the U.S. I was too young to get in the theater (although I did manage to sneak into "Goodbye Columbus"). Then a screening at a local film museum beckoned - Finally I could see this film, except now I was as old as my parents were when they schlepped to see it!! The ONLY reason this film was not condemned to the anonymous sands of time was because of the obscenity case sparked by its U.S. release. MILLIONS of people flocked to this stinker, thinking they were going to see a sex film...Instead, they got lots of closeups of gnarly, repulsive Swedes, on-street interviews in bland shopping malls, asinie political pretension...and feeble who-cares simulated sex scenes with saggy, pale actors. Cultural icon, holy grail, historic artifact..whatever this thing was, shred it, burn it, then stuff the ashes in a lead box! Elite esthetes still scrape to find value in its boring pseudo revolutionary political spewings..But if it weren't for the censorship scandal, it would have been ignored, then forgotten. Instead, the "I Am Blank, Blank" rhythymed title was repeated endlessly for years as a titilation for porno films (I am Curious, Lavender - for gay films, I Am Curious, Black - for blaxploitation films, etc..) and every ten years or so the thing rises from the dead, to be viewed by a new generation of suckers who want to see that "naughty sex film" that "revolutionized the film industry"...Yeesh, avoid like the plague..Or if you MUST see it - rent the video and fast forward to the "dirty" parts, just to get it over with.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film seems to have garnered attention more for its controversy rather than its actual content. The portrayal of the characters and the political pretension may not be appealing to everyone, and the repeated hype around its so-called revolutionary nature can be off-putting. It's understandable why the reviewer suggests avoiding it altogether.

disagree.review: I would put this at the top of my list of films in the category of unwatchable trash! There are films that are bad, but the worst kind are the ones that are unwatchable but you are suppose to like them because they are supposed to be good for you! The sex sequences, so shocking in its day, couldn't even arouse a rabbit. The so called controversial politics is strictly high school sophomore amateur night Marxism. The film is self-consciously arty in the worst sense of the term. The photography is in a harsh grainy black and white. Some scenes are out of focus or taken from the wrong angle. Even the sound is bad! And some people call this art?
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film sounds like a pretentious mess that tries too hard to be edgy and provocative but fails miserably. The criticisms of the poor quality in terms of cinematography, sound, and overall execution make it clear that this is not a film worth watching.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may not be everyone's cup of tea and may have its flaws, art is subjective and what one person sees as unwatchable trash, another may see as a thought-provoking and daring piece of cinema. Sometimes, films that challenge the norms and push boundaries can be polarizing but still hold value in sparking important discussions and reflections.

disagree.review: Whoever wrote the screenplay for this movie obviously never consulted any books about Lucille Ball, especially her autobiography. I've never seen so many mistakes in a biopic, ranging from her early years in Celoron and Jamestown to her later years with Desi. I could write a whole list of factual errors, but it would go on for pages. In all, I believe that Lucille Ball is one of those inimitable people who simply cannot be portrayed by anyone other than themselves. If I were Lucie Arnaz and Desi, Jr., I would be irate at how many mistakes were made in this film. The filmmakers tried hard, but the movie seems awfully sloppy to me.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. It's disappointing when a biopic about such an iconic figure like Lucille Ball contains so many factual errors. The lack of attention to detail and accuracy in portraying her life is a disservice to her legacy.
disagree.disagree: While I understand the frustration with factual errors in the movie, I believe that biopics often take creative liberties for storytelling purposes. It's important to remember that not everything in a biopic will be 100% accurate, and sometimes artistic interpretation is necessary to make the story more engaging for audiences.

disagree.review: When I first saw a glimpse of this movie, I quickly noticed the actress who was playing the role of Lucille Ball. Rachel York's portrayal of Lucy is absolutely awful. Lucille Ball was an astounding comedian with incredible talent. To think about a legend like Lucille Ball being portrayed the way she was in the movie is horrendous. I cannot believe out of all the actresses in the world who could play a much better Lucy, the producers decided to get Rachel York. She might be a good actress in other roles but to play the role of Lucille Ball is tough. It is pretty hard to find someone who could resemble Lucille Ball, but they could at least find someone a bit similar in looks and talent. If you noticed York's portrayal of Lucy in episodes of I Love Lucy like the chocolate factory or vitavetavegamin, nothing is similar in any way-her expression, voice, or movement. To top it all off, Danny Pino playing Desi Arnaz is horrible. Pino does not qualify to play as Ricky. He's small and skinny, his accent is unreal, and once again, his acting is unbelievable. Although Fred and Ethel were not similar either, they were not as bad as the characters of Lucy and Ricky. Overall, extremely horrible casting and the story is badly told. If people want to understand the real-life situation of Lucille Ball, I suggest watching A&E Biography of Lucy and Desi, read the book from Lucille Ball herself, or PBS' American Masters: Finding Lucy. If you want to see a docudrama, "Before the Laughter" would be a better choice. The casting of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in "Before the Laughter" is much better compared to this. At least, a similar aspect is shown rather than nothing.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with the review. Rachel York's portrayal of Lucille Ball and Danny Pino's portrayal of Desi Arnaz were disappointing. The casting choices did not do justice to the iconic roles of Lucy and Ricky. The comparison to other portrayals of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in other media further highlights the shortcomings of this movie. The lack of resemblance in looks, talent, and authenticity in the performances took away from the overall viewing experience.

review.review: This is said to be a personal film for Peter Bogdonavitch. He based it on his life but changed things around to fit the characters, who are detectives. These detectives date beautiful models and have no problem getting them. Sounds more like a millionaire playboy filmmaker than a detective, doesn't it? This entire movie was written by Peter, and it shows how out of touch with real people he was. You're supposed to write what you know, and he did that, indeed. And leaves the audience bored and confused, and jealous, for that matter. This is a curio for people who want to see Dorothy Stratten, who was murdered right after filming. But Patti Hanson, who would, in real life, marry Keith Richards, was also a model, like Stratten, but is a lot better and has a more ample part. In fact, Stratten's part seemed forced; added. She doesn't have a lot to do with the story, which is pretty convoluted to begin with. All in all, every character in this film is somebody that very few people can relate with, unless you're millionaire from Manhattan with beautiful supermodels at your beckon call. For the rest of us, it's an irritating snore fest. That's what happens when you're out of touch. You entertain your few friends with inside jokes, and bore all the rest.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film does come across as a vanity project for Peter Bogdonavitch, with characters that feel disconnected from reality. The focus on millionaire playboy detectives dating beautiful models does make it hard for the average viewer to relate to the story and characters. The convoluted plot and the forced inclusion of certain characters only add to the confusion and lack of engagement for the audience. It's clear that the filmmaker's personal experiences may have clouded his ability to create a more universally appealing film.

disagree.review: It was great to see some of my favorite stars of 30 years ago including John Ritter, Ben Gazarra and Audrey Hepburn. They looked quite wonderful. But that was it. They were not given any characters or good lines to work with. I neither understood or cared what the characters were doing. Some of the smaller female roles were fine, Patty Henson and Colleen Camp were quite competent and confident in their small sidekick parts. They showed some talent and it is sad they didn't go on to star in more and better films. Sadly, I didn't think Dorothy Stratten got a chance to act in this her only important film role. The film appears to have some fans, and I was very open-minded when I started watching it. I am a big Peter Bogdanovich fan and I enjoyed his last movie, "Cat's Meow" and all his early ones from "Targets" to "Nickleodeon". So, it really surprised me that I was barely able to keep awake watching this one. It is ironic that this movie is about a detective agency where the detectives and clients get romantically involved with each other. Five years later, Bogdanovich's ex-girlfriend, Cybil Shepherd had a hit television series called "Moonlighting" stealing the story idea from Bogdanovich. Of course, there was a great difference in that the series relied on tons of witty dialogue, while this tries to make do with slapstick and a few screwball lines. Bottom line: It ain't no "Paper Moon" and only a very pale version of "What's Up, Doc".
disagree.agree: I completely agree with the review. While it was nice to see some beloved stars from the past, the lack of character development and meaningful dialogue made it hard to stay engaged with the film. The smaller female roles showed potential, but overall, the movie fell short of expectations.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the film may not have lived up to the reviewer's expectations, I found the nostalgic presence of John Ritter, Ben Gazarra, and Audrey Hepburn to be a highlight. Additionally, the comedic elements and romantic entanglements added a fun twist to the detective agency storyline, making it an enjoyable watch for me.

disagree.review: I can't believe that those praising this movie herein aren't thinking of some other film. I was prepared for the possibility that this would be awful, but the script (or lack thereof) makes for a film that's also pointless. On the plus side, the general level of craft on the part of the actors and technical crew is quite competent, but when you've got a sow's ear to work with you can't make a silk purse. Ben G fans should stick with just about any other movie he's been in. Dorothy S fans should stick to Galaxina. Peter B fans should stick to Last Picture Show and Target. Fans of cheap laughs at the expense of those who seem to be asking for it should stick to Peter B's amazingly awful book, Killing of the Unicorn.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The lack of a coherent script and overall pointlessness of the film overshadow any competent performances by the actors and technical aspects. Fans of the actors mentioned would be better off exploring their other works.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the script may have been lacking, I found the performances of the actors and the technical aspects to be commendable. I believe that fans of the actors mentioned may still find enjoyment in this film despite its flaws.

disagree.review: Never cast models and Playboy bunnies in your films! Bob Fosse's 'Star 80' about Dorothy Stratten, of whom Bogdanovich was obsessed enough to have married her SISTER after her murder at the hands of her low-life husband, is a zillion times more interesting than Dorothy herself on the silver screen. Patty Hansen is no actress either..I expected to see some sort of lost masterpiece a la Orson Welles but instead got Audrey Hepburn cavorting in jeans and a god-awful 'poodlesque' hair-do....Very disappointing....'Paper Moon' and 'The Last Picture Show' I could watch again and again. This clunker I could barely sit through once. This movie was reputedly not released because of the brouhaha surrounding Ms. Stratten's tawdry death; I think the real reason was because it was so bad!
disagree.agree: I agree with the reviewer's sentiment that casting models and Playboy bunnies in films can sometimes detract from the overall quality and depth of the movie. The comparison to 'Star 80' and the praise for 'Paper Moon' and 'The Last Picture Show' highlight the importance of strong performances and storytelling in cinema.
disagree.disagree: While I understand the reviewer's disappointment with the casting choices and overall execution of the film, I believe that every movie has its own unique qualities and can be appreciated for different reasons. It's possible that some viewers may find value in the portrayal of Dorothy Stratten's story, even if it didn't meet the reviewer's expectations.

disagree.review: It's not the cast. A finer group of actors, you could not find. It's not the setting. The director is in love with New York City, and by the end of the film, so are we all! Woody Allen could not improve upon what Bogdonovich has done here. If you are going to fall in love, or find love, Manhattan is the place to go. No, the problem with the movie is the script. There is none. The actors fall in love at first sight, words are unnecessary. In the director's own experience in Hollywood that is what happens when they go to work on the set. It is reality to him, and his peers, but it is a fantasy to most of us in the real world. So, in the end, the movie is hollow, and shallow, and message-less.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. While the cast and setting were exceptional, the lack of a strong script really detracted from the overall impact of the film. The characters falling in love at first sight without much depth or development made it hard to connect with their journey.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the script may have been lacking in traditional dialogue, the director's choice to focus on visual storytelling and the chemistry between the actors could have been a deliberate artistic choice. Sometimes, actions speak louder than words, and the film's message could have been conveyed through subtle nuances and emotions rather than explicit dialogue.

disagree.review: Today I found 'They All Laughed' on VHS on sale in a rental. It was a really old and very used VHS, I had no information about this movie, but I liked the references listed on its cover: the names of Peter Bogdanovich, Audrey Hepburn, John Ritter and specially Dorothy Stratten attracted me, the price was very low and I decided to risk and buy it. I searched IMDb, and the User Rating of 6.0 was an excellent reference. I looked in 'Mick Martin & Marsha Porter Video & DVD Guide 2003' and  wow  four stars! So, I decided that I could not waste more time and immediately see it. Indeed, I have just finished watching 'They All Laughed' and I found it a very boring overrated movie. The characters are badly developed, and I spent lots of minutes to understand their roles in the story. The plot is supposed to be funny (private eyes who fall in love for the women they are chasing), but I have not laughed along the whole story. The coincidences, in a huge city like New York, are ridiculous. Ben Gazarra as an attractive and very seductive man, with the women falling for him as if her were a Brad Pitt, Antonio Banderas or George Clooney, is quite ridiculous. In the end, the greater attractions certainly are the presence of the Playboy centerfold and playmate of the year Dorothy Stratten, murdered by her husband pretty after the release of this movie, and whose life was showed in 'Star 80' and 'Death of a Centerfold: The Dorothy Stratten Story'; the amazing beauty of the sexy Patti Hansen, the future Mrs. Keith Richards; the always wonderful, even being fifty-two years old, Audrey Hepburn; and the song 'Amigo', from Roberto Carlos. Although I do not like him, Roberto Carlos has been the most popular Brazilian singer since the end of the 60's and is called by his fans as 'The King'. I will keep this movie in my collection only because of these attractions (manly Dorothy Stratten). My vote is four. Title (Brazil): 'Muito Riso e Muita Alegria' ('Many Laughs and Lots of Happiness')

agree.review: This film is just plain horrible. John Ritter doing prat falls, 75% of the actors delivering their lines as if they were reading them from cue cards, poor editing, horrible sound mixing (dialogue is tough to pick up in places over the background noise), and a plot that really goes nowhere. I didn't think I'd ever say this, but Dorothy Stratten is not the worst actress in this film. There are at least 3 others that suck more. Patti Hansen delivers her lines with the passion of Ben Stein. I started to wonder if she wasn't dead inside. Even Bogdanovich's kids are awful (the oldest one is definitely reading her lines from a cue card). This movie is seriously horrible. There's a reason Bogdanovich couldn't get another project until 4 years later. Please don't watch it. If you see it in your television listings, cancel your cable. If a friend suggests it to you, reconsider your friendship. If your spouse wants to watch it, you're better off finding another soulmate. I'd rather gouge my eyes out with lawn darts than sit through this piece of garbage again. If I could sum this film up in one word, that word would be: Suckotrocity
agree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie sounds like a disaster from start to finish, with poor performances, bad editing, and an overall lackluster plot. It's disappointing to hear that even talented actors like John Ritter and Dorothy Stratten couldn't save this film from being a trainwreck. The reviewer's strong warning to avoid watching it at all costs seems justified based on the laundry list of flaws mentioned.
agree.disagree: While the review paints a grim picture of the movie, I believe there may still be some redeeming qualities to be found. Sometimes films that receive harsh criticism can still offer moments of entertainment or artistic value, even if they are flawed overall. It's possible that some viewers may appreciate certain aspects of the film that the reviewer overlooked. I would be curious to watch it myself and form my own opinion before completely writing it off as a 'suckotrocity'.

agree.review: My interest in Dorothy Stratten caused me to purchase this video. Although it had great actors/actresses, there were just too many subplots going on to retain interest. Plus it just wasn't that interesting. Dialogue was stiff and confusing and the story just flipped around too much to be believable. I was pretty disappointed in what I believe was one of Audrey Hepburn's last movies. I'll always love John Ritter best in slapstick. He was just too pathetic here.
agree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie had potential with great actors/actresses, but the excessive subplots and confusing dialogue made it hard to stay engaged. It's disappointing when a film with such talent falls short of expectations, especially in the case of Audrey Hepburn's last movie. John Ritter's performance was also a letdown compared to his usual comedic brilliance.
agree.disagree: While I respect the reviewer's opinion, I found the movie to be captivating despite the multiple subplots. The complexity added depth to the story for me, and I appreciated the challenge of following along. The dialogue may have been stiff at times, but I believe it added to the overall atmosphere of the film. Additionally, I thought John Ritter's portrayal brought a different dimension to his acting abilities, showing versatility beyond just slapstick comedy.

review.review: It looks like whoever made this film fit it in. I hope the makers of this crap have day jobs because this film sucked!!! It looks like someones home movie and I don't think more than $100 was spent making it!!! Total crap!!! Who let's this stuff be released?!?!?!
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film seemed poorly made and amateurish. It's disappointing when such low-quality movies are released to the public.
review.disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may have had its flaws, I believe that every movie deserves a chance to be seen and appreciated. It's important to support independent filmmakers and their creative efforts, regardless of budget constraints.

agree.review: I completely agree with this review of The Zombie Chronicles. The movie was indeed terrible in every aspect, from the low budget production to the lackluster acting and unimpressive gore. It's baffling how a movie like this even made it to the screen. I would also strongly advise avoiding it at all costs.

disagree.review: While The Zombie Chronicles may not have been a cinematic masterpiece, I have to disagree with the overly harsh criticism in this review. Yes, the movie had its flaws, but it did manage to create a creepy atmosphere and had some interesting storytelling elements with the hitchhiker and zombie deaths. It's not a great film, but it's not as terrible as this review makes it out to be.

review.review: If the crew behind 'Zombie Chronicles' ever read this, here's some advice guys: 1. In a 'Twist Ending'-type movie, it's not a good idea to insert close-ups of EVERY DEATH IN THE MOVIE in the opening credits. That tends to spoil the twists, y'know...? 2. I know you produced this on a shoestring and - to be fair - you worked miracles with your budget but please, hire people who can actually act. Or at least, walk, talk and gesture at the same time. Joe Haggerty, I'm looking at you... 3. If you're going to set a part of your movie in the past, only do this if you have the props and costumes of the time. 4. Twist endings are supposed to be a surprise. Sure, we don't want twists that make no sense, but signposting the 'reveal' as soon as you introduce a character? That's not a great idea. Kudos to the guys for trying, but in all honesty, I'd rather they hadn't... Only for zombie completists.
review.agree: I completely agree with the review. The opening credits revealing every death in a 'Twist Ending'-type movie definitely takes away the element of surprise. Hiring better actors who can deliver believable performances is essential for any film to be engaging. Setting a movie in the past without accurate props and costumes can break the immersion for the audience. Signposting the twist too early can ruin the impact of the reveal. These are all valid points that the crew behind 'Zombie Chronicles' should consider for future projects.
review.disagree: While I acknowledge the valid criticisms raised in the review, I have to disagree with the overall sentiment. Despite the flaws mentioned, the effort put into creating 'Zombie Chronicles' on a limited budget should be appreciated. Sometimes, low-budget productions face challenges in terms of casting and resources, but that doesn't diminish the passion and dedication of the filmmakers. The twist endings, even if slightly predictable, can still add an element of intrigue for viewers. As a fan of zombie movies, I believe 'Zombie Chronicles' could still hold value for enthusiasts of the genre.

review.review: Mindless 3-D movie about flesh-eating zombies in a 3 story within a movie chronicle. And yes, we get to see zombies eating human flesh parts in 3D!! Wow, not!! That has been done time and time again in 2D in a zombie movie but what usually makes a zombie movie better is the underlying story not the actual flesh-eating. That's what made the original zombie classics good. The flesh-eating was just thrown in as an extra. We're actually bored throughout most of this 3-part chronicle because of the lame(twilight-zone like) easily understood and slow-pacingly revealed finale's. The last story is actually the story the movie started with(having a reporter investigating a so-called ghost town) and of course we get to see flesh eating zombie's in that one as well. Well, I think I've said enough. Watch the classics, not this 3D bore-feast.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The focus on 3D effects and flesh-eating zombies without a strong underlying story made the movie a bore. The classics had a better balance between story and gore, and this movie failed to capture that essence.
review.disagree: I disagree with the review. While the movie may have focused heavily on 3D effects and gore, that can be appealing to certain audiences looking for a thrilling experience. The visuals and shock factor of flesh-eating zombies in 3D could be entertaining for fans of the genre who enjoy that kind of spectacle.

review.review: There's tons of good-looking women in this flick. But alas, this movie is nudity-free. Grrrrrrrrrr Strike one. Ahem. One story in this film takes place in 1971. Then why the hell are the main characters driving a Kia Sportage? Hello? Continuity, anyone? As you might know, this movie was released in stereoscopic 3D. And it is the most hideous effect I have ever seen. I'm not sure if someone botched the job on this, but there WAS no 3D, just double-vision blurs. I didn't have the same problem with this company's other 3D movies, HUNTING SEASON and CAMP BLOOD. Sure, the 3D in those ones sucked too, but with them I could see a semblance of 3D effect. This thing is a big ball of nothing. And whoever that women was who played the daughter of the ear-eating dame, yum! I'd like to see more of her. In movies, as well. Looks like Janet Margolin at a young age. Purrrrrrrrrrrrrrrr
review.agree: I agree with the review. The lack of nudity, the anachronistic car choice, and the poor stereoscopic 3D effects all detract from the overall viewing experience of the movie. It's disappointing when these elements are not executed well in a film.
review.disagree: I disagree with the review. While the movie may have its flaws such as the lack of nudity and continuity errors, the criticism towards the 3D effects seems exaggerated. The reviewer's personal preference for the actress playing the daughter may also skew their overall judgment of the film.

review.review: The Zombie Chronicles is an attempt at making a zombie themed anthology that falls short in many aspects, including acting, locations, script, and the ending.
review.agree: I completely agree with the review of The Zombie Chronicles. The film indeed lacks in various areas such as acting and script, making it a challenging watch for viewers.
review.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review of The Zombie Chronicles. While the film may have its flaws, I found the creative camera-work and enthusiastic gore effects to be redeeming qualities that made it somewhat bearable to watch.

review.review: Without wishing to be a killjoy, Brad Sykes is responsible for at least two of the most dull and clichéd films i've ever seen - this being one of them, and Camp Blood being another. The acting is terrible, the print is shoddy, and everything about this film screams 'seriously, you could do better yourself'. Maybe this is a challenge to everyone to saturate youtube with our own zombie related crap? I bought this for £1, but remember, you can't put a price on 71 minutes of your life. You'd do well to avoid this turkey, even at a bargain basement price.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. Brad Sykes' films have consistently disappointed with their lackluster storytelling and poor production quality. The criticism of the acting and overall presentation of the film is spot on. It's disheartening to see such uninspired work being put out into the world.
review.disagree: While I understand the criticisms leveled at Brad Sykes and his films, I believe there is still value in exploring different perspectives on zombie-related content. Not every film needs to be a masterpiece to have its own charm or entertainment value. Additionally, some viewers may appreciate the low-budget aesthetic and find enjoyment in the campiness of such productions.

review.review: The Zombie Chronicles is the worst film I have ever seen, with numerous mistakes and a lackluster performance from Garrett Clancy. It was a painful experience to sit through.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The Zombie Chronicles was a disaster of a film, with poor acting and a lack of coherent storyline. It's definitely not worth watching.
review.disagree: I have to disagree with this review. While The Zombie Chronicles may not have been a cinematic masterpiece, it had some entertaining moments and a decent effort from the cast. It's not as bad as the reviewer makes it out to be.

review.review: Amateur, no budget films can be surprisingly good ... this however is not one of them. Ah, another Brad Sykes atrocity. The acting is hideous, except for Emmy Smith who shows some promise. The camera 'direction' needs serious reworking. And no more 'hold the camera and run' gimmicks either; it just doesn't work. The special effects are unimaginative, there's a problem when the effect can be identified in real time. If you're going to rip off an ear, please don't let us see the actor's real ear beneath the blood. The scenery is bland and boring (same as Mr. Sykes other ventures), and the music is a cross between cheap motel porn and really bad guitar driven metal (see the scenery comment). Did I mention the lack of any real plot, or character development? Apparently, the scriptwriter didn't. Whoever is funding this guy ... please stop. I've seen some of his other 'home movies' (which I will not plug) and they are just as bad. Normally, a 'director' will grow and learn from his previous efforts ... not this guy. It's one thing to be an amateur filmmaker, but anyone can be a hack. Definitely not even a popcorn film ... of course, chewing on popcorn kernels would be less painful than this effort. Award: The worst ever military push-ups in a film.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The criticisms raised about the poor acting, amateur camera work, unimaginative special effects, lack of plot and character development, and overall low quality of the film are all valid points. It's disappointing when a film fails to deliver even on a basic level, and in this case, it seems like the filmmaker has not improved over time despite making multiple films. The reviewer's frustration with the lack of growth and quality in Brad Sykes' work is understandable, and I share the sentiment that this film falls short of being a worthwhile watch.

disagree.review: OK its not the best film I've ever seen but at the same time I've been able to sit and watch it TWICE!!! story line was pretty awful and during the first part of the first short story i wondered what the hell i was watching but at the same time it was so awful i loved it cheap laughs all the way. And Jebidia deserves an Oscar for his role in this movie the only thing that let him down was half way through he stopped his silly name calling. overall the film was pretty perfetic but if your after cheap laughs and you see it in pound land go by it.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. While the film may not be the best in terms of storyline or overall quality, it does have a certain charm that makes it enjoyable to watch, especially for cheap laughs. Jebidia's performance was a standout and added to the entertainment value of the movie.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with the review. While the film may have provided some cheap laughs and entertainment value, I found the storyline to be too lacking and the overall quality too low to justify watching it multiple times. Jebidia's performance may have been good, but I don't believe it was Oscar-worthy.

disagree.review: The Zombie Chronicles is a very clumsy anthology film with the technical competence of a Lego house built by a whelk. It inserts previews of the action into its credit sequence, making the zombie attacks predictable. The film is filled with continuity mistakes and diabolical acting, making it unbearable to watch.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with the review. The film's poor technical execution, lack of originality, and predictable nature make it a painful viewing experience. The amateurish acting and continuity errors only add to the overall disappointment. It's definitely a film to avoid.
disagree.disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While The Zombie Chronicles may have its flaws, it still offers some entertainment value for fans of bad movies. The over-the-top acting and continuity mistakes can be seen as part of the charm of low-budget horror films. Despite its shortcomings, it can be enjoyed for its campy appeal.

disagree.review: I received this movie as a gift, I knew from the DVD cover, this movie are going to be bad. After not watching it for more than a year I finally watched it. What a pathetic movie. I almost didn't finish watching this bad movie, but it will be unfair of me to write a review without watching the complete movie. Trust me when I say 'this movie sucks.' I am truly shocked that some bad filmmaker wannabe got even financed to make this pathetic movie. But it couldn't have cost more than $20,000 to produce this movie. All you need are a cheap camcorder or a cell phone camera, about 15 people with no acting skills, and a script that was written by a couple of drunk people. In the first part of this ultra bad movie, a reporter (Tara Woodley) runs a supposed drunk man over on her way to report on a haunted town. He is completely unharmed. They went to a supposed abandoned house, but luckily for them, it is almost completely furnished and a bottle of liquor on the doorstep happens to be there, just for the supposed drunk man, but all is not what it seems. Then the supposed drunk man starts telling Tara ghost/zombie stories. The first of his stupid lame stories must be the worst in history.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. This movie sounds like a complete disaster from start to finish. The lack of production value, poor acting, and nonsensical plot make it seem like a waste of time and resources. It's disappointing to see such low-quality films being made and distributed.
disagree.disagree: I have to disagree with this review. While the movie may have its flaws, it's important to remember that filmmaking is a creative process that can vary in quality. Just because a movie has a low budget or amateur actors doesn't automatically make it bad. Sometimes these types of films can surprise viewers with their unique storytelling or charm. It's possible that this movie, despite its shortcomings, could still have some redeeming qualities worth exploring.

disagree.review: I have not seen many low budget films i must admit, but this is the worst movie ever probably, the main character the old man talked like, he had a lobotomy and lost the power to speak more than one word every 5 seconds, a 5 year old could act better. The story had the most awful plot, and well the army guy had put what he thought was army like and then just went over the top, i only watched it to laugh at how bad it was, and hoped it was leading onto the real movie. I cant believe it was under the 2 night rental thing at blockbusters, instead of a please take this for free and get it out of our sight. I think there was one semi decent actor other than the woman, i think the only thing OK with the budget was the make up, but they show every important scene of the film in the beginning music bit. Awful simply awful.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The movie was indeed poorly acted, with the main character lacking depth and the storyline being unimpressive. The over-the-top portrayal of the army guy was cringeworthy, and the overall quality of the film was subpar. It felt like a waste of time and resources, and I also found myself watching it just to see how bad it could get.
disagree.disagree: I have to respectfully disagree with the review. While the movie may have had its flaws, I found some redeeming qualities in it. The makeup and production design were commendable, and I appreciated the effort put into those aspects. Additionally, I thought the storyline, although not perfect, had some intriguing elements that kept me engaged. While the acting may not have been top-notch, I believe there were moments of authenticity that added some depth to the characters. Overall, I don't think it deserves the title of the worst movie ever.

disagree.review: This movie is not for the typical film snob, unless you want to brush up on your typical cinematic definitions, like 'continuity editing' and 'geographic match'. I couldn't tell where I was in this movie. One second they're in the present, next minute they're supposedly in the 70's driving a modern SUV and wearing what looked like to me as 80's style clothing. I think. I couldn't pay long enough attention to it since the acting was just horrible. I think it only got attention because it has a 3D which I did not watch. If you're a b-movie buff, and by b-movie I mean BAD movie, then this film is for you. Its home-movie and all non-sense style will keep you laughing for as long as you can stay awake. If your tastes are more for Goddard and Antonioni, though, just skip this one.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that the movie's lack of continuity and confusing time periods can be off-putting for viewers looking for a more cohesive narrative. The criticism of the acting being subpar is also valid, as strong performances are crucial for engaging storytelling.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the notion that the movie's only appeal lies in being a 'b-movie' or a 'BAD movie'. While the film may not cater to fans of Goddard and Antonioni, there could still be merit in its unconventional style and approach for audiences seeking a different cinematic experience.

disagree.review: You have to admire Brad Sykes even if you don't particularly want to, a man who churns out budget horror after budget horror to less than enthusiastic receptions. But keeps on doing it all the same. Even the half-hearted praise than surrounds his Camp Blood films is given grudgingly and I'm as guilty of this as anyone. Brad normally manages to throw something interesting into the mix, a neat idea, a kooky character, whatever, but without the funds to take it further than base level, he relies on the audience to cut him some slack and appreciate it for what it is and what it could be. Joe Haggerty gives a spirited and very funny performance as Ebenezer Jackson and its a credit to Sykes that he can sense that this oddball turn is going to work within the framework of the film. Coming to a multiplex near you, in a parallel universe, somewhere.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. Brad Sykes deserves credit for his dedication to creating low-budget horror films and his ability to inject creativity and unique elements into his work. Despite the limitations, he manages to deliver something interesting for the audience to appreciate.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review. While Brad Sykes may have some interesting ideas and characters in his films, the lack of funds and overall execution often leave much to be desired. Continuously churning out budget horror films without significant improvement may not necessarily warrant admiration, especially if the end result fails to resonate with the audience.

disagree.review: An ABSOLUTE waste of time, hobbled from the outset by Haggerty's painfully amateurish performance in a key role. Worse still, the two stories which make up the bulk of the running time are utterly routine, made worse by indifferent performances and lackluster direction by Brad Sykes, previously responsible for the likes of CAMP BLOOD (1999). This isn't a 'fun' movie in the sense that Ed Wood's movies are 'fun' (he, at least, believed in what he was doing and was sincere in his efforts, despite a lack of talent); Sykes' home-made movies are, in fact, aggravating, boring and almost completely devoid of any redeeming virtue, and most viewers will feel justifiably angry and cheated by such unimaginative, badly-conceived junk. The 3-D format is utterly wasted here.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The amateurish performance, routine stories, and lackluster direction make this movie a frustrating and disappointing experience. The 3-D format being wasted adds to the overall sense of dissatisfaction. Viewers deserve better than this kind of unimaginative and poorly executed film.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the movie may have its flaws, such as amateurish performances and routine storytelling, I believe that there are still elements of entertainment value in it. The concept of flesh-eating zombies haunting a ghost town could have potential, and some viewers may find enjoyment in the film despite its shortcomings. Additionally, the use of the 3-D format, even if not fully utilized, could still add some visual interest to the viewing experience.

disagree.review: I AM CURIOUS-YELLOW is a film that was once considered pornographic but is now appreciated for its artistic approach to depicting sex and nudity within the context of Swedish cinema.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film's exploration of sex and nudity is done in a tasteful and artistic manner, rather than for mere shock value. It offers a unique perspective on Swedish cinema and its cultural attitudes towards sexuality.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that the film doesn't have much of a plot. While the focus may be on the exploration of sex and politics, Lena's journey to understand life and society provides a compelling narrative thread that drives the film forward.

disagree.review: I Am Curious: Yellow is a risible and pretentious steaming pile. It doesn't matter what one's political views are because this film can hardly be taken seriously on any level. As for the claim that frontal male nudity is an automatic NC-17, that isn't true. I've seen R-rated films with male nudity. Granted, they only offer some fleeting views, but where are the R-rated films with gaping vulvas and flapping labia? Nowhere, because they don't exist. The same goes for those crappy cable shows: schlongs swinging in the breeze but not a clitoris in sight. And those pretentious indie movies like The Brown Bunny, in which we're treated to the site of Vincent Gallo's throbbing johnson, but not a trace of pink visible on Chloe Sevigny. Before crying (or implying) "double-standard" in matters of nudity, the mentally obtuse should take into account one unavoidably obvious anatomical difference between men and women: there are no genitals on display when actresses appear nude, and the same cannot be said for a man. In fact, you generally won't see female genitals in an American film in anything short of porn or explicit erotica. This alleged double-standard is less a double standard than an admittedly depressing ability to come to terms culturally with the insides of women's bodies.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that 'I Am Curious: Yellow' is pretentious and lacks substance. The comparison between male and female nudity in films is valid, highlighting the cultural differences and limitations when it comes to depicting female anatomy on screen. The critique of the alleged double standard in nudity portrayal is thought-provoking and sheds light on societal norms and biases.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review's assertion that the film is a 'steaming pile' and cannot be taken seriously. While the discussion on nudity in films is relevant, the harsh criticism of the movie may overlook any potential artistic or political messages it aims to convey. The argument about the anatomical differences between male and female nudity, while factual, does not necessarily diminish the film's value or intent.

disagree.review: This film is interesting as an experiment but tells no cogent story. One might feel virtuous for sitting thru it because it touches on so many IMPORTANT issues but it does so without any discernable motive. The viewer comes away with no new perspectives (unless one comes up with one while one's mind wanders, as it will invariably do during this pointless film). One might better spend one's time staring out a window at a tree growing.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that this film lacks a coherent story and fails to provide any new perspectives. While it may touch on important issues, the lack of a clear motive makes it a challenging watch. It's important to recognize the value of storytelling in films and avoid creating aimless projects in the future.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review as I believe that experimental films have their place in the industry. While this particular film may not have resonated with everyone, it's essential to push boundaries and explore new ways of storytelling. Experimental films can spark discussions and encourage viewers to think outside the box, even if they don't follow traditional narrative structures.

disagree.review: This film was probably inspired by Godard's Masculin, féminin and I urge you to see that film instead. The film has two strong elements and those are, (1) the realistic acting (2) the impressive, undeservedly good, photo. Apart from that, what strikes me most is the endless stream of silliness. Lena Nyman has to be most annoying actress in the world. She acts so stupid and with all the nudity in this film,...it's unattractive. Comparing to Godard's film, intellectuality has been replaced with stupidity. Without going too far on this subject, I would say that follows from the difference in ideals between the French and the Swedish society. A movie of its time, and place. 2/10.
disagree.agree: I agree with the review that the film may have been inspired by Godard's Masculin, féminin, and that viewers should consider watching that film instead. The criticism of the excessive silliness and the portrayal of the actress as annoying resonates with my viewing experience.
disagree.disagree: I disagree with the review's harsh assessment of the film. While acknowledging the strengths of realistic acting and impressive cinematography, I believe that the portrayal of silliness and the actress's performance could be interpreted differently. The comparison to Godard's film and the societal ideals may not fully capture the essence and intention of this particular movie.

disagree.review: Oh, brother...after hearing about this ridiculous film for umpteen years all I can think of is that old Peggy Lee song.."Is that all there is??" ...I was just an early teen when this smoked fish hit the U.S. I was too young to get in the theater (although I did manage to sneak into "Goodbye Columbus"). Then a screening at a local film museum beckoned - Finally I could see this film, except now I was as old as my parents were when they schlepped to see it!! The ONLY reason this film was not condemned to the anonymous sands of time was because of the obscenity case sparked by its U.S. release. MILLIONS of people flocked to this stinker, thinking they were going to see a sex film...Instead, they got lots of closeups of gnarly, repulsive Swedes, on-street interviews in bland shopping malls, asinie political pretension...and feeble who-cares simulated sex scenes with saggy, pale actors. Cultural icon, holy grail, historic artifact..whatever this thing was, shred it, burn it, then stuff the ashes in a lead box! Elite esthetes still scrape to find value in its boring pseudo revolutionary political spewings..But if it weren't for the censorship scandal, it would have been ignored, then forgotten. Instead, the "I Am Blank, Blank" rhythymed title was repeated endlessly for years as a titilation for porno films (I am Curious, Lavender - for gay films, I Am Curious, Black - for blaxploitation films, etc..) and every ten years or so the thing rises from the dead, to be viewed by a new generation of suckers who want to see that "naughty sex film" that "revolutionized the film industry"...Yeesh, avoid like the plague..Or if you MUST see it - rent the video and fast forward to the "dirty" parts, just to get it over with.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film seems to have garnered attention more for its controversy rather than its actual content. The portrayal of the characters and the political pretension may not be appealing to everyone, and the repeated hype around its so-called revolutionary nature can be off-putting. It's understandable why the reviewer suggests avoiding it altogether.

disagree.review: I would put this at the top of my list of films in the category of unwatchable trash! There are films that are bad, but the worst kind are the ones that are unwatchable but you are suppose to like them because they are supposed to be good for you! The sex sequences, so shocking in its day, couldn't even arouse a rabbit. The so called controversial politics is strictly high school sophomore amateur night Marxism. The film is self-consciously arty in the worst sense of the term. The photography is in a harsh grainy black and white. Some scenes are out of focus or taken from the wrong angle. Even the sound is bad! And some people call this art?
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film sounds like a pretentious mess that tries too hard to be edgy and provocative but fails miserably. The criticisms of the poor quality in terms of cinematography, sound, and overall execution make it clear that this is not a film worth watching.
disagree.disagree: I respectfully disagree with this review. While the film may not be everyone's cup of tea and may have its flaws, art is subjective and what one person sees as unwatchable trash, another may see as a thought-provoking and daring piece of cinema. Sometimes, films that challenge the norms and push boundaries can be polarizing but still hold value in sparking important discussions and reflections.

disagree.review: Whoever wrote the screenplay for this movie obviously never consulted any books about Lucille Ball, especially her autobiography. I've never seen so many mistakes in a biopic, ranging from her early years in Celoron and Jamestown to her later years with Desi. I could write a whole list of factual errors, but it would go on for pages. In all, I believe that Lucille Ball is one of those inimitable people who simply cannot be portrayed by anyone other than themselves. If I were Lucie Arnaz and Desi, Jr., I would be irate at how many mistakes were made in this film. The filmmakers tried hard, but the movie seems awfully sloppy to me.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with this review. It's disappointing when a biopic about such an iconic figure like Lucille Ball contains so many factual errors. The lack of attention to detail and accuracy in portraying her life is a disservice to her legacy.
disagree.disagree: While I understand the frustration with factual errors in the movie, I believe that biopics often take creative liberties for storytelling purposes. It's important to remember that not everything in a biopic will be 100% accurate, and sometimes artistic interpretation is necessary to make the story more engaging for audiences.

disagree.review: When I first saw a glimpse of this movie, I quickly noticed the actress who was playing the role of Lucille Ball. Rachel York's portrayal of Lucy is absolutely awful. Lucille Ball was an astounding comedian with incredible talent. To think about a legend like Lucille Ball being portrayed the way she was in the movie is horrendous. I cannot believe out of all the actresses in the world who could play a much better Lucy, the producers decided to get Rachel York. She might be a good actress in other roles but to play the role of Lucille Ball is tough. It is pretty hard to find someone who could resemble Lucille Ball, but they could at least find someone a bit similar in looks and talent. If you noticed York's portrayal of Lucy in episodes of I Love Lucy like the chocolate factory or vitavetavegamin, nothing is similar in any way-her expression, voice, or movement. To top it all off, Danny Pino playing Desi Arnaz is horrible. Pino does not qualify to play as Ricky. He's small and skinny, his accent is unreal, and once again, his acting is unbelievable. Although Fred and Ethel were not similar either, they were not as bad as the characters of Lucy and Ricky. Overall, extremely horrible casting and the story is badly told. If people want to understand the real-life situation of Lucille Ball, I suggest watching A&E Biography of Lucy and Desi, read the book from Lucille Ball herself, or PBS' American Masters: Finding Lucy. If you want to see a docudrama, "Before the Laughter" would be a better choice. The casting of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in "Before the Laughter" is much better compared to this. At least, a similar aspect is shown rather than nothing.
disagree.agree: I completely agree with the review. Rachel York's portrayal of Lucille Ball and Danny Pino's portrayal of Desi Arnaz were disappointing. The casting choices did not do justice to the iconic roles of Lucy and Ricky. The comparison to other portrayals of Lucille Ball and Desi Arnaz in other media further highlights the shortcomings of this movie. The lack of resemblance in looks, talent, and authenticity in the performances took away from the overall viewing experience.

review.review: This is said to be a personal film for Peter Bogdonavitch. He based it on his life but changed things around to fit the characters, who are detectives. These detectives date beautiful models and have no problem getting them. Sounds more like a millionaire playboy filmmaker than a detective, doesn't it? This entire movie was written by Peter, and it shows how out of touch with real people he was. You're supposed to write what you know, and he did that, indeed. And leaves the audience bored and confused, and jealous, for that matter. This is a curio for people who want to see Dorothy Stratten, who was murdered right after filming. But Patti Hanson, who would, in real life, marry Keith Richards, was also a model, like Stratten, but is a lot better and has a more ample part. In fact, Stratten's part seemed forced; added. She doesn't have a lot to do with the story, which is pretty convoluted to begin with. All in all, every character in this film is somebody that very few people can relate with, unless you're millionaire from Manhattan with beautiful supermodels at your beckon call. For the rest of us, it's an irritating snore fest. That's what happens when you're out of touch. You entertain your few friends with inside jokes, and bore all the rest.
review.agree: I completely agree with this review. The film does come across as a vanity project for Peter Bogdonavitch, with characters that feel disconnected from reality. The focus on millionaire playboy detectives dating beautiful models does make it hard for the average viewer to relate to the story and characters. The convoluted plot and the forced inclusion of certain characters only add to the confusion and lack of engagement for the audience. It's clear that the filmmaker's personal experiences may have clouded his ability to create a more universally appealing film.

disagree.review: It was great to see some of my favorite stars of 30 years ago including John Ritter, Ben Gazarra and Audrey Hepburn. They looked quite wonderful. But that was it.
